sub_topic: Solving non-homogeneous systems of linear equations
message_1:
Solve the following non-homogeneous system of linear equations:
    
    3x + 2y - z = 7
    4x - 3y + z = 2
    x + y + 2z = 1

Note: The system is non-homogeneous because of the constants on the right-hand side of the equations.
message_2:
To solve the non-homogeneous system of linear equations, we can use the method of substitution or elimination. In this case, we will use the elimination method.

First, we will eliminate z from the first two equations by adding them:

(3x + 2y - z) + (4x - 3y + z) = 7 + 2
7x - y = 9
y = 7x - 9 (1)

Now, we will eliminate z from the second and third equations:

(4x - 3y + z) - 2(x + y + 2z) = 2 - 2(1)
4x - 3y + z - 2x - 2y - 4z = 0
2x - 5y + 3z = 0 (2)

Now, we will substitute equation (1) into equation (2):

2x - 5(7x - 9) + 3z = 0
2x - 35x + 45 + 3z = 0
-33x + 45 + 3z = 0
3z = 33x - 45 (3)

Now, we will substitute equation (1) into the third equation:

x + (7x - 9) + 2z = 1
8x - 9 + 2z = 1
2z = -8x + 10 (4)

Now, we will equate equations (3) and (4):

33x - 45 = -8x + 10
41x = 55
x = 55/41
x = 5/3

Now, we will substitute the value of x into equation (1):

y = 7(5/3) - 9
y = 35/3 - 27/3
y = 8/3

Finally, we will substitute the values of x and y into equation (4):

2z = -8(5/3) + 10
2z = -40/3 + 30/3
2z = -10/3
z = -5/3

So, the solution to the non-homogeneous system of linear equations is:

x = 5/3, y = 8/3, and z = -5/3.
